Graphical abstract The formation of hydrogen sulfide in car exhaust is undesirable due to unpleasant odor and toxicity of H2S gas. H2S release can be suppressed by the addition of a NiO scavenger to a three-way catalyst (TWC). In this work, Pd–Ni bimetallic catalysts were prepared by the co-addition of Pd and Ni to γ-Al2O3 or Al2O3-La2O3 support, by the impregnation method. Different concentrations of a propionic acid aqueous solution were used as the impregnation solvent. The structure of prepared catalysts was characterized by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET), X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) techniques. Catalyst poisoning by SO2 was simulated under lean conditions and H2S release under rich conditions. XRD and TPR measurements revealed the effect of the impregnation solvent concentration on the ratio between NiO and NiAl2O4 spinel species and the reducibility of Ni species. Co-addition of Pd with Ni was proven to be beneficial for H2S suppression. Prepared bimetallic catalysts released considerably less H2S compared to physical mixtures of Pd/Al2O3 with NiO. The presence of bulk and well dispersed NiO on Pd–Ni catalysts assisted in sulfur release in the form of sulfur oxides rather than H2S. Bimetallic catalysts supported on Al2O3-La2O3 were found to release more H2S compared to catalysts on γ-Al2O3. The use of diluted solvent in bimetallic catalysts preparation decreased H2S release from Pd–Ni catalysts. Keywords Pd-Ni catalysts NiAl2O4 spinel SO2 poisoning H2S release under rich conditions 1 Introduction Toxic gases that originate from car engines are a well known source of air pollution. Carbon monoxide, short hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides are formed during the incomplete combustion of fuel in the engines. In order to reduce the emissions of the engines, three-way catalytic converters (TWC) are installed into the exhaust systems of gasoline cars [1–3]. The main components of the TWC are active metals, like Pt, Pd, Rh, dispersed over large surface area supports [4–6]. Palladium is a common choice of the active metal due to its high catalytic activity, thermal stability, and low volatility [7–11]. Aluminum oxide, cerium oxide, zirconium oxide, and their combinations are well-known supports that possess high thermal stability [2,3,10–14]. While alumina provides a large surface area for high metal dispersion, ceria and zirconia act as oxygen storage materials. Modern TWCs are required to perform with high activity and have long-term stability under high operating temperatures and in the presence of catalyst poisons. Sulfur is a known poison of the Pd-based TWC systems. Sulfur can enter into the TCW system from sulfur-containing gasoline fuels or from lubricant oils. Adsorption of sulfur on the Pd catalysts reduces the number of active sites and consequently conversion of the exhaust gas decreases [15–19]. Regeneration of the sulfur-poisoned catalysts is commonly attained by adjusting the air to fuel ratio [17,19,20]. Adjustment of the air to fuel ratio towards the slightly rich side removes sulfur chemisorbed on the catalyst surface. Nonetheless, under the rich conditions chemisorbed sulfur reacts with hydrogen to form H2S [5,21]. The presence of H2S in the cars’ exhaust is undesirable due to the consequent unpleasant odor and toxicity. For this reason, the addition of a second metal, capable of binding sulfur, to the TWC has been considered [22]. It has been concluded that the presence of NiO in the TWC prevents both catalyst poisoning and formation of H2S [5,23–25]. A Ni scavenger has been commonly added to the TWC by the physical mixing of NiO with the TWC [23,25]. The disadvantage of such a preparation method can be a weak contact between Ni and the support. Therefore, within the long-term work, loss of the nickel component due to attrition can be possible. Moreover, free NiO can come into contact with CO and form a toxic Ni-carbonyl compound. The formation of Ni-carbonyl can be minimized by the addition of a Ni-containing catalyst into a close-coupled position near the engine. In order to obtain a stronger contact between Ni and support, Ni can be added to the TWC by the impregnation method. Co-impregnated Pd–Ni bimetallic catalysts have been tested in TWC reactions and the activities of the resultant catalysts were in line with the activities of the monometallic Pd catalysts [26–28]. However, it has been concluded that the discovered Ni species on the co-impregnated Pd–Ni catalysts differ from bulk NiO. Calcined bimetallic catalysts have been found to consist of bulk NiO, well dispersed NiO, and pseudo-spinel NiAl2O4. On the other hand, aging of the bimetallic catalysts under high temperature transformed major part of the Ni species into a NiAl2O4 spinel phase [28]. In well dispersed NiO and NiAl2O4 spinel phases, stronger Ni-support interactions have been discovered and consequently higher thermal stability of Ni species has been obtained. Since bulk NiO has been a common Ni phase used in H2S suppression, fewer studies have considered the possible formation of other Ni phases [29]. Investigation of the effect of different Ni species on the H2S suppression properties of Pd-Ni catalysts can be of great importance. The aim of this study is to prepare a catalyst capable of preventing H2S release under rich operating conditions. Pd–Ni bimetallic catalysts will be prepared by the impregnation method. The effect of the impregnation solvent concentration on the ratio between NiO and Ni spinel phases will be examined. Sulfur adsorption and release properties of the catalysts will be tested and compared to commonly used Pd monometallic catalysts and the physical mixture of NiO with Pd catalyst. The effect of NiO and Ni spinel species on sulfur adsorption and release properties of Pd-Ni catalysts will be evaluated based on the amount of H2S released. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation In this study, supported mono- and bimetallic Pd-Ni catalysts were prepared by the wet impregnation method and by physical mixing. γ-Al2O3 (Sasol, particle size distribution <25μm 37.8%, <45μm 64.4%, and <90μm 92.0%) or γ-Al2O3 promoted with La2O3 (3wt.% La2O3, particle size distribution <25μm 36.4%, <45μm 64.4%, and <90μm 98.6%) were employed as support materials. Palladium was introduced in a form of Pd(acac)2 precursor. Ni(NO3)2 6H2O precursor was used for Ni deposition by the impregnation method. For the physical mixtures, NiO was prepared by calcining Ni(NO3)2 6H2O precursor in an oven at 550°C for 2h. Propionic acid (Fluka, p.a.) was used as the impregnation solvent for monometallic Pd catalysts. Water was used as the impregnation solvent for monometallic Ni catalysts. Aqueous propionic acid solutions of 50, 75 and 100vol.% concentrations were used as the impregnation solvents for bimetallic Pd–Ni catalysts. Palladium loading was adjusted to 3wt.% and nickel loading to 9wt.%. Monometallic catalysts were prepared by impregnating a metal precursor on the support. The dissolved precursor was mixed with the support under continuous stirring at room temperature for 24h, followed by evaporation of the solvent at 145°C for 10h. Calcination was carried out in air at 550°C for 2h, the resultant catalysts were denoted as fresh. A portion of each fresh catalyst was aged in air at 900°C for 4h. Bimetallic catalysts were prepared by the impregnation-evaporation method described elsewhere [28]. In short, Pd and Ni precursors were added simultaneously to the solvent and mixed with the support, followed by the same preparation procedure described for the monometallic samples. Physical mixtures of NiO were prepared by mixing NiO with γ-Al2O3 support or Pd monometallic catalyst in water at room temperature for 24h followed by the drying, calcination, and aging steps described for the monometallic samples. Composition and designation of the catalysts prepared for this study are summarized in Table 1 . Pd-containing catalysts are denoted as xPd-Niy and xPd-Niy-La. Where La refers to γ-Al2O3 promoted with La2O3, x is the concentration of propionic acid in the solutions, and y is the loading of Ni in the catalyst. Monometallic Ni samples are denoted as yNi-W, where y is the Ni weight loading and W stands for water impregnation solvent. Physical mixtures include mixture of NiO with monometallic Pd catalyst (9NiO+Pd) or with γ-Al2O3 support (9NiO+Al). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The specific surface areas of the catalysts were measured by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method (BET) with a Quantachrome autosorb ASiQwin device. Prior to the experiment, a portion of each catalyst (220mg) was pretreated under vacuum at 350°C for 3h. The measurements were carried out at the temperature of liquid nitrogen using nitrogen gas as an adsorbate. Each catalyst was tested three times. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded with a Bruker-AXD D8 Advance device using Cu Kα as a radiation source. The diffraction patterns were recorded at a 2θ angle range from 12° to 90° with a scanning speed of 0.11° min−1. The PdO crystallite sizes were estimated with TOPAS software on the basis of the XRD patterns [30]. Pd dispersion was calculated on the basis of PdO crystallite size [28,31]. Firstly, the specific metal surface area was calculated from the PdO crystallite size obtained from XRD measurements: (1) A m = x × f 100 × ρ × d , where, A m is the specific metal surface area (m2 g−1), χ is the metal loading (3wt.% for Pd), f is a shape factor (6 for sphere), ρ is Pd density (12.02×10−6 gm−3), and d is PdO crystallite size (m). Metal dispersion was calculated from Eq. (2): (2) δ = M A m A x × L a v × 100 χ × 100 % , where, δ is the metal dispersion (%), M is the molecular weight of the metal (gmol−1), A x is a cross-sectional area of each atom (m2), and L Av is Avogadro’s number (6.022×1023) [31]. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR-H2) measurements were performed with a Quantachrome autosorb ASiQwin device. The samples were pretreated at 300°C for 2h under continuous N2 flow (30cm3 min−1) and then cooled to room temperature. After cooling, the gas was changed to 10% H2 in Ar (20cm3 min−1) and a TPR measurement was performed by heating the samples from room temperature to 1000°C (10°C min−1). TPR profiles were recorded by using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and quadrupole mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer PrismaPlus™ Mass Spectrometer). Water, formed during reduction, was collected before the TCD in a cold trap. Surface characterization was performed by using a Hitachi S4800 FE-SEM (Scanning Electron Microscopy) device. The Thermo Electron Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) device was used to produce a detailed surface characterization. The surface composition was studied with 20kV accelerating voltage and 10μA current at a 15mm working distance. Sulfur adsorption/release properties of prepared catalysts were studied with a Quantachrome autosorb ASiQwin device. Sulfur adsorption was performed under O2 excess at 400°C for 4h under a continuous flow of 100ppm SO2 in N2 mixed with technical air at a ratio of 90:1 (30cm3 min−1). Following the adsorption, the samples were evacuated under 10% O2 in He flow (20cm3 min−1) at 400°C for 1h to remove physically adsorbed species. Sulfur desorption was monitored during the sample heating from room temperature to 1000°C (10°C min−1) under 10% H2 in Ar flow (20cm3 min−1). Sulfur desorption profiles were recorded with the use of a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer PrismaPlus™ Mass Spectrometer). Sulfur elemental analysis was performed by using an Elementar vario MICRO cube micro-analyzer with simultaneous carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, and sulfur determination. The sulfur content of the samples was analyzed after sulfur adsorption and desorption. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts color observations Ni phase on the monometallic Ni catalysts can be distinguished based on the sample color [32,33]. The colors of the monometallic Ni samples before and after aging are listed in Table 2 . Pure NiO powder has grey-green coloration. For this reason, the presence of bulk NiO species can be expected on 9NiO+Al and the fresh 9Ni-W-La catalysts. Light green coloration of Ni/Al2O3 samples has been previously attributed to the presence of well dispersed NiO or a pseudo-spinel Ni phase [32]. A light green color was detected on the fresh 9Ni-W and on the aged 9NiO+Al. Aged 9Ni-W and 9Ni-W-La catalysts had a light blue color, indicating the presence of a NiAl2O4 spinel phase. The color difference of Ni supported on γ-Al2O3 and on Al2O3-La2O3 can be explained by the difference in Ni dispersion on the supports. Alumina doped with La initially has a lower surface area compared to alumina and, thus, less surface sites are available for the interaction of Ni precursor with support. Therefore, support with a lower amount of surface sites will have lower Ni dispersion and a higher amount of bulk NiO, as seen in the case of the fresh 9Ni-W-La sample. During aging, Ni transforms into a spinel structure on both 9Ni-W and 9Ni-W-La catalysts. Based on the current observations, it can be concluded that the temperature treatment affects Ni-support interaction and, consequently, the phase composition of the samples. 3.2 BET surface areas The surface areas of prepared catalysts are summarized in Table 3 . The surface area loss was detected for all the prepared samples after aging. Addition of Ni decreased the surface area of the bimetallic catalysts compared to the monometallic Pd samples. A higher surface area loss after the addition of Ni was detected for bimetallic catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 compared to catalysts supported on Al2O3-La2O3. One possible reason could be the formation of NiO interacting strongly with a support that can potentially block some of the support pores. The solvent concentration had a minor effect on the surface area of the bimetallic catalysts. 3.3 Powder X-ray diffraction The XRD patterns of prepared mono- and bimetallic Pd–Ni catalysts are presented in Fig. 1 . The XRD results of the monometallic Pd catalysts indicate the presence of PdO and γ-Al2O3 diffraction peaks on the fresh samples and additional metallic Pd peaks on the aged samples. The patterns of the fresh Pd-Ni catalysts include characteristic diffraction peaks of bulk NiO at 2θ values of 43° and 63.4° [34,35]. The area of NiO peaks increases with a decreasing concentration of solvent for fresh Pd–Ni catalysts supported on both γ-Al2O3 and Al2O3-La2O3. The presence of the NiO phase is less distinguishable on the aged Pd–Ni catalysts and monometallic Ni catalysts. A considerably lower area of NiO peaks suggests a higher degree of NiO dispersion or the formation of a different nickel phase on the aged catalysts. On the XRD patterns of the aged Ni-containing catalysts the reflection peak of γ-Al2O3 at ≈66° shifted toward lower 2θ values. The peak shift has been previously assigned to the existence of a NiAl2O4 spinel phase [28,32,36,37]. The shift is similar for all bimetallic catalysts prepared from different solvent concentrations. XRD diffraction patterns of NiO physical mixtures were identical to combined XRD patterns of NiO and γ-Al2O3 or Pd/γ-Al2O3 and, therefore, not shown in this paper. The sizes of PdO and NiO crystallites were estimated from the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 34° and 43° respectively, and are shown in Table 3. The size of NiO crystallites increases with a decreasing concentration of solvent. Moreover, on the La-containing catalysts NiO already forms distinguishable crystallites at high solvent concentrations. On the other hand, on a pure alumina support it is possible to measure NiO crystallite size only for catalysts prepared from 50% solvent concentration. The larger size of NiO crystallites on Al2O3-La2O3 support can be explained by the weaker Ni-support interaction, as was discussed above (Section 3.1). The effect of solvent concentration on the size of NiO crystallites can be explained by the different decomposition temperatures of materials used for catalyst preparation. It has been previously concluded that alumina can interact with carboxylic acids, forming materials similar to carboxylato-alumoxanes [38,39]. The formation of bonds between aluminum and carboxylic acid can later promote metal-exchange reactions of an aluminum cation with another metal cation. In this study alumina was mixed with Pd and Ni precursors in a propionic acid solution, allowing the formation of carboxylato-alumoxane type bonds. The drying of obtained slurry was conducted at the temperature above the evaporation temperature of Ni nitrate precursor. Therefore, during the drying step interaction of Ni with a carboxylato-alumoxane complex could occur, resulting in an Al-Ni cation exchange. When propionic acid diluted in water was used as the impregnation solvent, fewer bonds between aluminum and carboxylic acid were formed and, thus, a lower amount Al-Ni exchanges occurred. For this reason, fresh Pd-Ni catalysts prepared with a diluted solvent had a higher amount of bulk NiO. The aging of the resulted catalysts reduced the amount of bulk NiO on the surface, by transforming bulk NiO into either well dispersed NiO or NiAl2O4 spinel structure. The size of the PdO crystallites was affected by the addition of Ni in the bimetallic Pd-Ni catalysts. The growth of the PdO crystallite size in the presence of Ni was previously explained by the Pd-Ni competition for the support sites during catalyst preparation [28]. It was claimed that the formation of PdO and NiO on the support does not occur simultaneously when Pd(acac)2 and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O precursors are co-added to the support. With the Ni-support structure formed during the drying step, less surface sites would be available for Pd-support interaction during the calcination step. As a result, the formation of larger PdO crystallites can be expected on the bimetallic Pd–Ni catalysts. The PdO crystallite sizes of the aged catalysts are nearly 10nm larger than in the case of the fresh catalysts. The increase in the PdO crystallite size after aging is the result of Pd agglomeration under high temperatures [12]. 3.4 Temperature programmed reduction TPR profiles of the monometallic Ni catalysts are presented in Fig. 2 . The TPR profiles of the fresh Ni catalysts contained H2 consumption peaks attributed to the reduction of well dispersed NiO (peak 2) and NiAl2O4 spinel (peak 3) [36,37,40–42]. The reduction peak of well dispersed NiO interacting strongly with the support will be hereafter referred to as NiO-S. Additionally, the small peak of the bulk NiO reduction (peak 1) can be seen on the TPR profiles of the fresh 9Ni-W-La catalyst at the temperature range of 400–500°C [28,40,41,43]. Aged Ni catalysts dominantly consisted of NiAl2O4 spinel (peak 3) [36,37,44,45]. Reduction of the NiO-S species on the aged samples produced a small peak that overlaps with the NiAl2O4 spinel peak for the temperature range of 650–800°C (peak 2). The fresh 9Ni-W and 9Ni-W-La catalysts had different ratios of NiO-S and NiAl2O4 peaks. On the fresh 9Ni-W catalysts the amount of the spinel phase was slightly higher than that of the NiO phase. On the other hand, on the fresh 9Ni-W-La catalysts the amount of the NiO phase was higher than in the case of the NiAl2O4 spinel phase. The difference of the Ni phase composition of 9Ni-W and 9Ni-W-La catalysts can be due to a different amount of surface sites available on γ-Al2O3 and Al2O3-La2O3 for Ni-support interaction. A lower surface area of Al2O3-La2O3 support limits the amount of surface sites available for Ni to form a more stable spinel structure. On the other hand, aging of the 9Ni-W-La catalyst resulted in the formation of NiAl2O4 spinel structure reducible at higher temperature than in the case of the 9Ni-W catalyst. The amount of the NiAl2O4 spinel phase on the aged 9Ni-W and 9Ni-W-La catalysts cannot be compared, since the reduction peaks of the spinel phase are incomplete. Based on the TPR observations, it can be concluded that the choice of support can affect the reducibility of the Ni species and the ratio between NiO and NiAl2O4 spinel on the catalyst surface. TPR profiles of NiO physical mixtures with γ-Al2O3 support and with the 100Pd-Ni0 catalyst are shown in Fig. 3 . The low temperature peak of H2 evolution (peak 4) of the 9NiO+Pd catalysts is attributed to the decomposition of Pd hydrate [46]. With increasing temperature, multiple peaks of hydrogen consumption emerge on the reduction profiles of the NiO physical mixtures. The first two hydrogen consumption peaks for the range of 250–350°C and 350–500°C can be assigned to the reduction of surface NiOx species (peak 4) and bulk NiO (peak 1) interacting weakly with the support [28,40,41,43,47]. Reduction peaks at higher temperature ranges of 500–800°C and 780–1000°C are due to the reduction of well dispersed NiO (peak 2) and NiAl2O4 spinel structure (peak 3) [40,43,47]. In the fresh physical mixtures, nickel was found dominantly in the form of surface and bulk NiO. The aging of the physical mixtures resulted in the formation of well dispersed NiO and NiAl2O4 spinel. The presence of Ni species reducible at higher temperatures suggests the influence of high temperature treatment on the Ni-support interaction. Therefore, NiO introduced to catalyst by physical mixing with no initial interaction with the support can also form a more thermally stable species over time under high temperature exposure. Fresh Pd-Ni catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 and Al2O3-La2O3 had Ni species which appeared at similar reduction temperatures and, for this reason, the TPR profiles of the fresh Pd–Ni catalysts are not shown in the paper. The TPR profiles of the aged bimetallic catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 and on Al2O3-La2O3 are compared in Fig. 4 . Reduction of the bimetallic catalysts produces a single peak of H2 evolution and multiple peaks of H2 consumption. The first peak of H2 evolution is similar to peak 4 recorded on the physical mixture of NiO with Pd catalyst and can be assigned to decomposition of Pd hydrate. Reduction peak 1 at the temperature range of 350–500°C can be attributed to the reduction of bulk NiO [28]. The presence of reduction peak 2 at the temperature range of 500–800°C is hardly noticeable due to overlap with peak 3 of higher intensity. Peak 2 appears on the TPR profiles due to the reduction of well dispersed NiO and peak 3 due to reduction of NiAl2O4 spinel [43]. Comparison of the TPR profiles of aged catalysts on different supports reveals the effect of the solvent concentration on the reducibility of Ni species. A decrease in the solvent concentration in the series of catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 results in a minor shift of the NiAl2O4 spinel peak toward lower temperatures. In the case of aged catalysts supported on Al2O3-La2O3, the shift of the spinel peak with decreasing solvent concentration is more pronounced. Therefore, the use of diluted carboxylic acids in catalyst preparation leads to weaker Ni-support interaction and, consequently, formation of Ni species reducible at lower temperatures compared to catalysts prepared from 100% carboxylic acid. Moreover, the choice of support can affect the reducibility of the Ni species. On the TPR profiles of the aged catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3, highest H2 consumption by NiAl2O4 spinel species is at temperatures of about 810°C, while for the aged catalysts on Al2O3-La2O3, highest H2 consumption is above 830°C. Based on the later observation it can be concluded that La promoter facilitates the formation of more thermally stable NiAl2O4 spinel species. H2 consumption peaks attributed to the reduction of Ni species on the Pd–Ni catalysts were integrated and the resultant amount of H2 consumption is presented in Fig. 5 . Ni species detected on the fresh catalysts were present in the form of bulk NiO, well dispersed NiO and NiAl2O4 spinel. The ratio between Ni species on the fresh catalysts is greatly affected by the solvent concentration. A decrease in solvent concentration increases the amount of bulk NiO and decreases the amount of well dispersed NiO. A similar trend was discovered from evaluation of the XRD patterns of the fresh Pd-Ni catalysts. Therefore, metal exchange reaction between Al and Ni atoms can be promoted in the presence of concentrated carboxylic acids, resulting in stronger Ni-support interaction. On the other hand, tuning the ratio of bulk NiO to well dispersed NiO on the catalyst surface is possible by adjusting the impregnation solvent concentration. Moreover, the presence of La on the support affects the amount of NiO species favoring formation of bulk NiO. Aging of the bimetallic catalysts transforms major part of Ni into spinel structure, Fig. 5b. A very low amount of bulk NiO can be detected on the aged catalysts. The influence of a solvent concentration on the ratio between Ni species can be detected on the aged catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3. Weaker Ni-support interactions in catalysts prepared from diluted propionic acid lead to a larger amount of well dispersed NiO and a lower amount of spinel structure, compared to catalysts prepared from concentrated acid. However, the effect of solvent concentration is negligible in the case of aged catalysts supported on Al2O3-La2O3. The ratio between Ni species remains almost unaffected by the solvent concentration. The later observation suggests the presence of stronger Ni-support interaction in the aged Pd-Ni9-La catalysts compared to Pd-Ni9 catalysts. 3.5 Scanning electron microscopy Surface examination of the bimetallic Pd-Ni catalysts revealed the presence of separate PdOx particles on the fresh catalysts and agglomerated PdOx particles on the aged catalysts, Fig. 6 . Bimetallic catalysts prepared from a diluted propionic acid had larger PdOx particles, compared to catalysts prepared from concentrated acid. The average size of PdOx agglomerated particles, detected on the aged catalysts surface, was 100–150nm. On the other hand, NiO particles were not observed on the surface of Ni-containing catalysts prepared by impregnation, possibly due to high Ni dispersion or the small size of the NiO particles. EDS analysis confirmed uniform distribution of nickel on the surface of both fresh and aged catalysts. The size and the distribution of NiO particles in the bimetallic Pd–Ni catalysts were not affected by the solvent concentration used in catalysts preparation. The presence of NiO agglomerates was detected on the surface of 9NiO+Al and 9NiO+Pd physical mixtures and is shown in Fig. 7 . NiO agglomerates were distributed irregularly on the surface of the physical mixtures. The observed agglomerates had asymmetrical shape and the size ranging from below 80nm to 600nm. Aging of the physical mixtures had a minor effect on the size of NiO agglomerates; more uniform distribution of NiO was detected on some parts of the aged catalysts surface. The size and the distribution of PdOx agglomerated particles on the aged 9NiO+Pd were not affected by the presence of NiO and remained similar to the aged 100Pd-Ni0 catalyst. 3.6 Sulfur elemental analysis The sulfur content of all tested samples was measured by elemental analysis after sulfur adsorption and desorption experiments and are summarized in Table 4 . The sulfur tests on supports and pure NiO confirmed their ability to adsorb sulfur under a lean atmosphere. In a rich atmosphere, all sulfur was released from supports and only a minor amount of sulfur remained on NiO. The fresh 9NiO+Al mixture adsorbed and released the same amount of sulfur as γ-Al2O3 and NiO individually. However, after aging, the amount of sulfur adsorbed by the physical mixture decreased, while the amount of sulfur remaining after desorption increased. Therefore, changes in the structure of the 9NiO+Al mixture after aging reduced the amount of S-adsorption sites. Simultaneously, the amount of Ni sites capable of forming stronger Ni-S bonds increased. Based on the phase composition of 9NiO+Al mixtures estimated from TPR measurements, it can be suggested that Ni sites which both adsorb and release sulfur are bulk NiO detected on the fresh mixtures. The sites that formed stronger NiS bonds would be either well dispersed NiO or NiAl2O4 spinel detected on the aged mixtures. The addition of Ni to support by impregnation changes the sulfur adsorption/release properties of the support. Fresh 9Ni-W and 9Ni-W-La adsorb and release the same amount of sulfur. The amount of sulfur remaining on the fresh monometallic Ni samples after desorption is higher compared to the physical mixture of NiO with support. Therefore, well dispersed NiO or NiAl2O4 spinel sites of monometallic Ni samples detected by TPR could be participating in the formation of strong Ni-S bonds. Aged 9Ni-W contains more sulfur after adsorption and release than 9Ni-W-La. The reason could be the presence of well dispersed NiO or NiAl2O4 spinel species, reducible at lower temperatures on the aged 9Ni-W catalyst. According to the later observation, not only the amount of Ni species affects NiS bonding, but also the relative reducibility of the Ni species. Fresh monometallic Pd catalysts adsorb the same amount of sulfur as pure supports, though in the case of aged Pd catalysts the amount of adsorbed sulfur is higher. After desorption some sulfur still remains on the monometallic Pd catalysts, indicating formation of PdS bonds. The amount of sulfur remaining on Pd catalysts after desorption is nearly the same for fresh and aged Pd catalysts. It can be expected that sulfur poisons similar Pd sites in both fresh and aged Pd catalysts. The effect of Ni addition to Pd catalysts on the sulfur adsorption/release properties of bimetallic catalysts is unclear, since Pd, Ni, and alumina sites participate in the sulfur adsorption. 3.7 H2S release under rich conditions The release of H2S under rich conditions was monitored by mass spectrometer (MS). Recorded H2S signals of the supports, monometallic samples, and NiO physical mixtures are presented in Fig. 8 . The amount of H2S released from γ-Al2O3 is higher than from Al2O3-La2O3, possibly due to a higher amount of surface sites available on γ-Al2O3 for sulfur adsorption. Monometallic Pd catalysts release H2S at higher temperatures compared to pure supports. An increase in the H2S desorption temperature in the presence of Pd suggests the formation of stronger PdS bonds compared to supportS bonds. Aged monometallic Pd catalysts release more H2S than fresh Pd catalysts. A different amount of H2S released from Pd catalysts implies the presence of weaker PdS bonds in the aged catalysts and stronger PdS bonds in the fresh ones. Alternatively, some of sulfur could be released in a form of SO2 or SO3 from the fresh Pd catalysts. The MS signal of SO2 disappears from desorption profiles of monometallic catalysts at temperatures around 140°C and the signal of SO3 disappears at 250°C. Therefore, in the low temperature region sulfur can be desorbed in the form of sulfur oxides. Pure NiO releases H2S in the higher temperature region compared to monometallic Pd catalysts. On the other hand, no H2S release was detected from the fresh 9Ni-W and 9Ni-W-La catalysts, while elemental analysis confirmed loss of sulfur after desorption. Therefore, sulfur adsorbed on the fresh monometallic Ni catalysts was released in a form different from H2S. Consequently, Ni species adsorbing and releasing sulfur in monometallic Ni catalysts can be expected to differ from bulk NiO. Aged 9Ni-W and 9Ni-W-La catalysts release H2S at the temperature region of 350–600°C. The temperature of H2S release of the aged Ni catalysts is lower compared to the H2S release temperature of pure supports, 500–700°C, and bulk NiO, 800–1000°C. Therefore, sites releasing H2S from the aged Ni catalysts differ from alumina support sites or bulk NiO. Additionally, fresh and aged Ni catalysts have different sites for sulfur adsorption, since fresh Ni catalysts do not release H2S. The differences in the phase composition of fresh and aged Ni catalysts were discovered by TPR measurements. A high amount of well dispersed NiO and NiAl2O4 spinel was detected on the fresh Ni catalysts, while aged catalysts consisted of dominantly NiAl2O4 spinel phase. Therefore, it can be concluded that on the fresh Ni catalysts well dispersed NiO sites assist sulfur release in the form of sulfur oxides. On the other hand, on the aged Ni catalysts presence of NiAl2O4 spinel sites results in a sulfur release as H2S. Furthermore, in the presence of La a higher amount of H2S is released from the aged Ni catalysts. One possible reason is the higher thermal stability of the NiAl2O4 spinel phase in the aged 9Ni-W-La catalysts and, consequently, a weaker Ni-S bond compared to the aged 9Ni-W catalysts. A fresh physical mixture of NiO with alumina releases more H2S compared to the aged mixture. The reason could be changes in the catalyst structure after aging. TPR analysis of aged physical mixtures confirmed a decrease of surface and bulk NiO sites and an increase of NiAl2O4 species reducible at higher temperatures. A fresh physical mixture of NiO with Pd catalyst releases a low amount of H2S at higher temperatures than the aged mixture. Both aged physical mixtures release H2S in the same temperature region. Therefore, on the aged physical mixtures H2S could be released from similar surface sites assigned to either bulk NiO or NiAl2O4 spinel. Desorption signals of H2S recorded from the bimetallic Pd–Ni catalysts with 10X magnification are shown in Fig. 9 . The amount of H2S released from the bimetallic catalysts is insignificant compared to the monometallic samples. No H2S release was detected from the fresh bimetallic samples. Sulfur could be released from the fresh bimetallic catalysts in the form of sulfur oxides, similarly to the fresh Ni catalysts. Aged bimetallic catalysts release a minor amount of H2S at the temperature region similar to aged physical mixtures of NiO, 500–800°C. The sites assisting H2S release from the aged bimetallic catalysts can be assigned to NiAl2O4 spinel sites, since aged bimetallic catalysts contained a large amount of spinel and a very low amount of NiO. The temperature region of H2S release from NiAl2O4 spinel sites of aged Pd–Ni catalysts is higher compared to aged Ni catalysts. Higher temperatures of H2S release can be explained by better reducibility of NiAl2O4 spinel in the bimetallic catalysts, resulting in stronger NiS bonds. Additionally, aged bimetallic catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 were found to release less H2S compared to aged catalysts on Al2O3-La2O3. The lower amount of released H2S could be due to the better reducibility of the NiAl2O4 spinel species of the aged Pd-Ni catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3. The effect of solvent concentration on H2S release properties of the bimetallic catalysts can be distinguished in the case of aged Pd–Ni catalysts. With a decrease in solvent concentration the amount of released H2S decreases. The reason could be different Ni reducibility and a different ratio of NiO to NiAl2O4 spinel of Pd–Ni catalysts prepared from different solvent concentrations. In the case of aged Pd-Ni9 catalysts, the amount of well dispersed NiO increases with decreasing solvent concentration. As was concluded, the presence of well dispersed NiO facilitates the release of sulfur in oxide form. Moreover, with decreasing solvent concentration the reducibility of NiAl2O4 spinel species increases, leading to the formation of stronger Ni-S bonds. On the other hand, aged Pd-Ni9-La catalysts have a minor change in the NiO to NiAl2O4 spinel ratio with changing solvent concentrations. As a result, H2S release was detected from all aged catalysts containing La. However, a decrease in solvent concentration reduced the amount of H2S released, possibly due to improved reducibility of NiAl2O4 spinel in Pd-Ni9-La catalysts prepared from diluted solvent. 4 Conclusions In this study, bimetallic Pd–Ni catalysts were prepared by the impregnation-evaporation method with varying carboxylic acid concentrations of the impregnation solvent. Based on the XRD and TPR characterization it was found that the state of Ni species on the bimetallic catalysts is affected by the solvent concentration. On the fresh bimetallic catalysts, Ni was detected in the form of bulk NiO, well dispersed NiO, and NiAl2O4 spinel. The TPR measurement revealed an increasing amount of bulk NiO with a decreasing solvent concentration of the fresh Pd–Ni catalysts. The opposite effect was detected for well dispersed NiO species. Aging of the bimetallic catalysts transformed major part of the Ni species into a NiAl2O4 spinel structure. A low amount of Ni remained in the oxide form after aging. The obtained spinel structure had a higher thermal stability compared to Ni in oxide form. The reducibility of the NiAl2O4 spinel species was improved on the aged Pd–Ni catalysts prepared from a diluted solvent. Prepared bimetallic catalysts were tested for sulfur adsorption and release ability, and compared to a commonly used physical mixture of NiO with Pd catalysts. Co-impregnated Pd–Ni catalysts released considerably less H2S than corresponding monometallic samples or physical mixtures with NiO. Moreover, Pd–Ni catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 release less H2S compared to catalysts on Al2O3-La2O3. H2S release properties of the bimetallic Pd–Ni catalysts were found to be affected by the ratio between NiO and NiAl2O4 spinel species and the reducibility of NiAl2O4 spinel. The presence of well dispersed NiO was found to prevent sulfur release in the form of H2S. Moreover, bimetallic catalysts containing NiAl2O4 spinel phase reducible at lower temperatures were found to release less H2S. For this reason, use of diluted carboxylic acids as the impregnation solvent can reduce H2S release from Pd–Ni bimetallic catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The formation of hydrogen sulfide in car exhaust is undesirable due to unpleasant odor and toxicity of H2S gas. H2S release can be suppressed by the addition of a NiO scavenger to a three-way catalyst (TWC). In this work, Pd–Ni bimetallic catalysts were prepared by the co-addition of Pd and Ni to γ-Al2O3 or Al2O3-La2O3 support, by the impregnation method. Different concentrations of a propionic acid aqueous solution were used as the impregnation solvent. The structure of prepared catalysts was characterized by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET), X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) techniques. Catalyst poisoning by SO2 was simulated under lean conditions and H2S release under rich conditions. XRD and TPR measurements revealed the effect of the impregnation solvent concentration on the ratio between NiO and NiAl2O4 spinel species and the reducibility of Ni species. Co-addition of Pd with Ni was proven to be beneficial for H2S suppression. Prepared bimetallic catalysts released considerably less H2S compared to physical mixtures of Pd/Al2O3 with NiO. The presence of bulk and well dispersed NiO on Pd–Ni catalysts assisted in sulfur release in the form of sulfur oxides rather than H2S. Bimetallic catalysts supported on Al2O3-La2O3 were found to release more H2S compared to catalysts on γ-Al2O3. The use of diluted solvent in bimetallic catalysts preparation decreased H2S release from Pd–Ni catalysts.
